posts.title: Understanding Callback Functions in JavaScript
posts.body:
Today I deepened my understanding of how callback functions work in JavaScript.
I learned that a callback is simply a function passed as an argument to another function, allowing that function to run after a specific task completes.
It’s super useful for handling asynchronous operations like API calls or event listeners.
For example, I built a small function that fetches user data and then calls another function to display it once the data loads — it helped solidify the concept of “functions as first-class citizens” for me!

posts.title: Mastering Async/Await for Cleaner Code
posts.body:
Today I learned how using async and await can make asynchronous code much easier to read and maintain.
Instead of chaining multiple .then() calls, I rewrote my API requests with await, and it felt almost like writing synchronous code.
I also realized how important try...catch blocks are for handling errors in async functions — they keep everything clean and predictable.
Understanding how promises work behind the scenes made this click for me. Async/await really simplifies working with asynchronous logic in JavaScript!
